review.title: A Model for Safety Case Confidence Assessment
review.abstract: Building a safety case is a common approach to make expert judgement explicit about safety of a system. The issue of confidence in such argumentation is still an open research field. Providing quantitative estimation of confidence is an interesting approach to manage complexity of arguments. This paper explores the main current approaches, and proposes a new model for quantitative confidence estimation based on Belief Theory for its definition, and on Bayesian Belief Networks for its propagation in safety case networks.

sections.heading: 5.1 Argument Types
sections.text: The very basic conclusion is the simplest: "A is supported by B." Nevertheless, most arguments are more complex than direct one-to-one conclusions. Consider, for example, the example presented with the main claim "A: System is usable," which is supported by both "B: Tests are conclusive" and "C: Formal verification has been performed." In this case, we can expect both proofs to independently increase confidence in A. This concept is presented in [20] as an "alternative argument": even if there is no confidence in B, the fact that C also independently supports A will maintain a certain degree of confidence. sections.text: Complementary arguments are used when a set of solutions or objectives are required at the same time to support the main objective q = 1. sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: We argue that it is important to have a separation between the security case and the trust case. Our goal is to analyze uncertainties that can arise in a security case, using sensitivity analysis. Our approach is based on the Dempster-Shafer theory for the definitions of trust and uncertainty. However, the constraint m (X, X) = 0 brings the main advantage of using mathematical tools, such as BBN. Therefore, for most common security case models in GSN, we have proposed some transformation rules in a trust network. In particular, we introduce the use of loud or alternative arguments and an adapted version of loud and complementary arguments. An experiment on a real case study of a rehabilitation robot [15] has been carried out.
